t: For the director of music. For Jeduthun. A psalm of David.
I*pn said, “I will watch my ways and*ld keep my tongue from sin; I*ln will put a muzzle on my mouth while*ld in the presence of the wicked.”
So*ln I remained utterly silent, not*ld even saying anything good. But*ln my anguish increased;
my*ld heart grew hot within me. While*ln I meditated, the fire burned; then*ld I spoke with my tongue:
“Show*pn me, Lord,*s my life’s end and*ld the number of my days; let*ld me know how fleeting my life is.
You*ln have made my days a mere handbreadth; the*ld span of my years is as nothing before you. Everyone*ln is but a breath, even*ld those who seem secure.
“Surely*pn everyone goes around like a mere phantom; in*ld vain they rush about, heaping up wealth without*ld knowing whose it will finally be.
“But*pn now, Lord, what do I look for? My*ld hope is in you.
Save*ln me from all my transgressions; do*ld not make me the scorn of fools.
I*ln was silent; I would not open my mouth, for*ld you are the one who has done this.
Remove*ln your scourge from me; I*ld am overcome by the blow of your hand.
When*ln you rebuke and discipline anyone for their sin, you*ld consume their wealth like a moth— surely*ld everyone is but a breath.
“Hear*pn my prayer, Lord,*s listen*ld to my cry for help; do*ld not be deaf to my weeping. I*ln dwell with you as a foreigner, a*ld stranger, as all my ancestors were.
Look*ln away from me, that I may enjoy life again before*ld I depart and am no more.”
